title: @Reds / @Meddler, How do YOU feel about patch 5.5?
body:
I know the big mission with these changes (and S5 as a whole) was to create jungler diversity, which this patch seems to have finally accomplished. We've seen some of the most entertaining eSports games to date just in the past couple days with fresh picks galore. The great majority of the community seems to be supportive of these changes. But aside from the initial question, I have some others.

Do you feel patch 5.5 is your "Mission Accomplished" as far as jungler diversity goes?
How do you feel about the recent eSports picks?
With "League of Tanks" making a comeback, will some top laners also receive some well deserved love? 
Are there any other significant jungle changes we can expect?

replies.body:
My personal take is that 5.5 seems to have been very positive for the game, at least so far. Haven't had a chance to make it through all the recent competitive games yet, heartening to see some champs played that haven't been seen there in quite a while though. Hope at least some of that increase in diversity's maintained.

I wouldn't say 5.5 was 'mission accomplished' though, just a piece of the puzzle. One of the next things we're looking at is some further work on the jungle items (Skirmisher's and Poacher's aren't used much at the moment and there good reasons for that - they're generally pretty overshadowed).

I dare say the only group of Junglers you've left out are mages. Tanks clear by soaking up damage and AoE DoT'ing camps down over time with abilities and Cinderhulk, AD Champions AA camps down, and Mages go OOM trying to spam abilities to clear then end up with nothing in reserve when they go to gank a lane.

Please change Magus next and give it Mana drain or something.

Magus is the proverbial Double Doran's Rings of the Jungle, or the Jungler's alternative to Morello's/Athene's - just with no mana sustain at all.

Just so you know, that's also a pretty huge buff to jungle Nidalee, which is a pretty bad idea imo, she's already plenty strong. Most mages that jungle that I've seen, notably Fiddlesticks and Karthus, seem to do fine with sustain from Rangers, blue buff, and a tear if necessary. Magus is already incredibly gold efficient, and I don't think the necessary jungler item should just solve all the junglers problems, especially when there are cheap mana regen options already in the store, like tear or idol, or even double dorans

> Most mages that jungle that I've seen, notably Fiddlesticks and Karthus, seem to do fine 

You understand the flaw in this reasoning, right?  You only see a few mages jungle because the rest can't handle the mana requirements.

Exactly. Who knows who may become viable. Hell Brand has % max HP shredding and strong CC, would have fast clears if not for mana issues. His mana running dry turns him from

http://25.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_ltsoagX3Hw1qlmow4o1_500.jpg

Into

http://vignette4.wikia.nocookie.net/lasmacabrasaventurasdebillyymandy/images/a/a6/Toadblatt_anciano.png/revision/latest?cb=20090516232400&path-prefix=es

No, you only see a few mages in junglers because there's actually a reason for taking them into jungle besides "lol i feel like it" or "lol champion diversity". Squishy, damage focused champions in general (there are some exceptions) have issues in jungle; this is the same reason you don't see ADCs or a lot of assassins in jungle (and no, mana is not an issue for ADCs, Zed, Akali, etc. lol).

If you're having trouble with early clear, hey, Magus isn't going to do jack to help you. If you're having trouble sustaining mana later in the game, hey, maybe you should have built some mana regen instead of seven deathcaps and complaining that mages have mana issues. If you're having mana issues, take Rangers' smite, smite your blue, build a tear or forbidden idol after your t2 machete upgrade before you finish magus, and if you're *really* spam heavy, change up your runes and masteries. If mana is *really* the only issue preventing mages from jungling, there are plenty of ways around it; the fact that there *are* mages (pretty mana hungry mages at that) that successfully jungle is a testament to that.

It's like complaining that Cinderhulk doesn't also give armor and MR, plus tenacity and CDR. For real, there are other items in the game, people, no one's forcing you down a single build path

> [{quoted}](name=MrBuffington,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iZVXNjno,comment-id=00000000000100000002,timestamp=2015-03-23T18:18:36.796+0000)
>
> No, you only see a few mages in junglers because there's actually a reason for taking them into jungle besides "lol i feel like it" or "lol champion diversity". Squishy, damage focused champions in general (there are some exceptions) have issues in jungle; this is the same reason you don't see ADCs or a lot of assassins in jungle (and no, mana is not an issue for ADCs, Zed, Akali, etc. lol).

Let me be clear.  Here are some junglers that make sense in the role, but you currently can't play because of mana issues:
{{champion:268}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:50}} {{champion:90}} {{champion:127}} 

I really don't like this theory that squishy, damage-focused champions should generally not jungle.  I want the strategic diversity that was proposed in the season 5 changes.  I think the game gets better if you can play assassins and mages in the role without feeling like an idiot, and it opens up new possibilities for how to play mid and top lane too.

> If you're having trouble with early clear, hey, Magus isn't going to do jack to help you. If you're having trouble sustaining mana later in the game, hey, maybe you should have built some mana regen instead of seven deathcaps and complaining that mages have mana issues. If you're having mana issues, take Rangers' smite, smite your blue, build a tear or forbidden idol after your t2 machete upgrade before you finish magus, and if you're *really* spam heavy, change up your runes and masteries. If mana is *really* the only issue preventing mages from jungling, there are plenty of ways around it; the fact that there *are* mages (pretty mana hungry mages at that) that successfully jungle is a testament to that.

I don't think making Magus enchantment the answer to mana sustain will work.  I just think there's a real problem here.

I think your proposed solutions for mana sustain aren't worth the cost.  Better to take another jungler as the game is designed today.

* Azir doesn't make sense as a jungler to me; he has so many advantages in lane and is too item reliant to be an effective jungler. I've seen NB3 play him when he first came out, honestly it was pretty underwhelming.

* Diana does fine in jungle; she doesn't even build mana as it stands now and she seems to do just fine, especially since a lot of her clear is based on her attack speed and passive.

* Swain always has mana issues, even if he's a laner; the issue is more with Swain than with jungle mana sustain.

* I've seen AD Malzahar jungle wreck people already, he just builds a Tear and he's good to go. I don't really see the reasoning behind bringing AP Malzahar into jungle.

* Never seen Lissandra jungle, I suspect you just play around your passive better and you'll be fine, worse case build an idol/morellonomicon, she already needs CDR

My thing is, I don't see the reason for just randomly throwing champions into jungle for "lol champion diversity". Mages as a class aren't well suited for jungle, much like ADCs they're pretty gold reliant, as well as exp reliant, both of which are pretty lacking in jungle. Their damage is largely ability focused, much like a lot of tank junglers, so their clear speed is innately lackluster compared to AD champs, not to mention they're not even tanky to be able to sustain damage like tank junglers (plus they nerfed that soft leashing since it was pretty abusive).

If you can make a case for a *particular* champion, sure, buff them to better be able to jungle if they can't already (or can't perform at a high level equal to their peers). I don't really see mana sustain as a huge issue, and if it is, it's not exclusive to mages nor the issue that prevents a lot of mages from jungling, and even so, not one that can't be worked around, even if you might dislike the costs. I'm sure every single mid lane mage in the game would love to be able to skip Athene's/Morellonomicon and just build pure damage/utility while getting mana sustain and CDR for free; there are pros and cons to virtually everything in this game, sometimes you have to learn how to min/max your builds and playstyle in order to do what you want, instead of just praying for Riot to give you a free lunch.

> Never seen Lissandra jungle, I suspect you just play around your passive better and you'll be fine, worse case build an idol/morellonomicon, she already needs CDR

Any jungle build that doesn't involve finishing your jungler item first is inefficient.  This is why the fix for tank junglers was to make a new tank jungler item, rather than say pushing the Sunfire line as an early buy.  This is also why, if you want Magus to be a thing on more than just a couple champs, you need to have mana itemization in its build path.

As for the part about playing around her passive better, I recommend you take Lissandra into a custom game and try to clear the jungle for a few minutes.  One free spell every 18 seconds is totally not going to cut it.

> My thing is, I don't see the reason for just randomly throwing champions into jungle for "lol champion diversity". Mages as a class aren't well suited for jungle, much like ADCs they're pretty gold reliant, as well as exp reliant, both of which are pretty lacking in jungle. 

Some mages are high gold, high exp champions.  Quite a few aren't.  We run many mages as supports because they are quite good at providing utility without needing a ton of resources to be effective.

> Their damage is largely ability focused, much like a lot of tank junglers, so their clear speed is innately lackluster compared to AD champs, not to mention they're not even tanky to be able to sustain damage like tank junglers (plus they nerfed that soft leashing since it was pretty abusive).

Do you think it's desirable for AD to be inherently superior to AP for jungling?  It wasn't always this way.  It doesn't have to be this way.
 
> I'm sure every single mid lane mage in the game would love to be able to skip Athene's/Morellonomicon and just build pure damage/utility while getting mana sustain and CDR for free; there are pros and cons to virtually everything in this game, sometimes you have to learn how to min/max your builds and playstyle in order to do what you want, instead of just praying for Riot to give you a free lunch.

It's not a matter of altering my playstyle; for most mages, there is no playstyle that works well enough to be competitive.  The tools currently in the game for jungle mana sustain simply don't support most AP champions in the jungle.

This is a new problem.  Didn't exist in season 4, because Spirit Stone was a thing.

> Any jungle build that doesn't involve finishing your jungler item first is inefficient. This is why the fix for tank junglers was to make a new tank jungler item, rather than say pushing the Sunfire line as an early buy.

This is a really narrow way to look at the game; if you look at S4 Rengar builds, you'd often go madreds -> mobi boots, a lot of pro junglers didn't even finish their jungler item. And this is the build that would allow Rengar to snowball out of control.

Also putting your completed jungle item on hold to buy a tear is vastly different than trying to build a whole sunfire cape; that's why they also introduced an intermediate sunfire-esque item in bami's cinder instead of just putting sunfire cape's effect onto the jungle item.

> As for the part about playing around her passive better, I recommend you take Lissandra into a custom game and try to clear the jungle for a few minutes. One free spell every 18 seconds is totally not going to cut it.

I'm saying you have to learn to use it better. Or build mana regen. Her passive has built in CDR that allows her to have it up more frequently; if that's *still* not enough, that's why you build mana regen or take regen blues instead of CDR since you can build morello's and have 40% with magus.

As a jungler you're always scrapping together items since you have innately less gold and exp income than a laner; it's naive to expect to have identical impact as a laner when you innately have fewer resources to work with; you have to *adapt* to the role, it isn't just a plug and play thing. Example: Top lane Olaf builds *a lot* of damage, jungle Olaf builds pure tank. Jungle Lissandra is never going to do as much damage as lane Lissandra unless she's stupidly fed, so you focus on other aspects she can bring to the table, namely her CC (in which case having CDR is vital).

> Some mages are high gold, high exp champions. Quite a few aren't. We run many mages as supports because they are quite good at providing utility without needing a ton of resources to be effective.

And many of them function fine currently as junglers too, it's just you have to *adapt* them to the role. If you're playing support Morgana, you think it's *efficient* for her to build sightstone? No, she could deal a ton more damage and have a ton more utility in fights by just saving that gold for a different item; the reason you build it is because it's a necessary component of that role. You bring Morgana into the jungle, you have to find a way to *adapt* her to the jungle instead of just expecting to play her like lane Morgana without any difference. Other elements of her kit will be emphasized, damage is most likely not the prime concern (especially since it will always be less than a lane Morgana's, as I mentioned with Lissandra, since you innately have less gold income).

> Do you think it's desirable for AD to be inherently superior to AP for jungling? It wasn't always this way. It doesn't have to be this way.

I think it's really limited to think of this game in terms of AD and AP; think about your champion and *why* you're actually playing them in a certain role. Honestly look at the champions being played in jungle and why they're there: do you see a lot of glass cannon AD champions going in jungle? No. It's basically Shaco and Master Yi (to which I counter with Fiddlesticks and Karthus). What makes you think glass cannon AP champions should be an exception? Most of the AD champions are bruisers or off-tanks, most of the AP champions are tanks; if anything there's just a lack of AP bruisers in the champion roster (the ones I can think of are Diana, Gragas, and Nidalee; guess what, they're junglers).

> This is a new problem. Didn't exist in season 4, because Spirit Stone was a thing.

And Rangers + Blue buff smite + forbidden Idol are things in season 5. *There are ways to adapt to the game*. If it were the case that you've exhausted every single option and still have no way of functioning as a mage jungler, go ahead and complain away, but I suspect that's not the case because *I've seen mages work in jungle* (I'm not even talking about just Fiddlesticks and Karthus). Yes, I know the jungle is mathematically more difficult in s5; I don't think it's so bad that you can't make things work. 

Moreover, I don't really see jungle mages as an entire class as something that Riot needs to devote time and effort to blanket-supporting, especially where there are larger issues, especially since the rewards to promoting the entire *class* of champions seem pretty vacuous, and especially when it's still possible to make your off-meta build work given the tools available. Again, if you want a specific champion to be able to jungle more effectively, go ahead and and make an argument for them specifically. I think it's irresponsible and ill advised to have a massive blanket buff if you just want to support a tiny niche aspect of the game.

> This is a really narrow way to look at the game; if you look at S4 Rengar builds, you'd often go madreds -> mobi boots, a lot of pro junglers didn't even finish their jungler item. And this is the build that would allow Rengar to snowball out of control.

The S5 jungle enchants are so efficient as to be the only thing you can build first in any rational jungler build.  For example, as an AD jungler, blue smite into cutlass is obviously incorrect.  Brutalizer is the only correct choice, because warrior is supremely gold efficient given that you have bought a jungler item.

The jungle items from S4 didn't have this problem.

> Most of the AD champions are bruisers or off-tanks, most of the AP champions are tanks

This is an accurate description of what currently is.  It doesn't have to be this way.  Making the jungle the province of only a specific subset of champions is one of the big reasons why DotA meta feels so much more open than LoL meta.  

The jungle meta heavily influences the lane meta.  If only one kind of jungler can be played, that means that only laners who synergize well with that type of jungler can be played.

> And Rangers + Blue buff smite + forbidden Idol are things in season 5. *There are ways to adapt to the game*. If it were the case that you've exhausted every single option and still have no way of functioning as a mage jungler, go ahead and complain away

If you buy ranger's, take all the blues, and get an early idol chain item, you are obviously less useful than the meta junglers.

> I've seen mages work in jungle

Where?  I'd wager it's not at any interesting level of play.

> Again, if you want a specific champion to be able to jungle more effectively, go ahead and and make an argument for them specifically. I think it's irresponsible and ill advised to have a massive blanket buff if you just want to support a tiny niche aspect of the game.

From my perspective, Magus doesn't work in the same way that Juggernaut didn't work.  For tanks, the problem was that buying Juggernaut didn't help with clears.  For mages, it's that buying Magus doesn't offer them enough mana to clear. This is the same core problem, and the same type of solution will work.

> The S5 jungle enchants are so efficient as to be the only thing you can build first in any rational jungler build.

...??? You build whatever you need in a certain situation. If you're vs. a mage mid lane and you're just getting poked out and bullied, you don't just blindly go morellonomicon because you saw it in LCS, you suck up the extra couple hundred gold to go chalice for the MR. It's the same thing. You buy situationally, that's how the game has always worked. You buy boots when you actually need boots. You buy wards when you need wards (which is pretty much always). You buy defense when you need defense. It's the same thing for regen. I'm not saying you complete morellonomicon, I'm saying you buy a cheap intermediate item that helps you play your role more effectively. You have six item slots for a reason, they're a *resource* that you use to be as effective as possible in your role.

> Where? I'd wager it's not at any interesting level of play.

Watch NB3 do his A-Z series; he plays every "jungler" (he's got a loose definition of who can jungle, so he's playing stuff like Brand as a jungler) in challenger or high diamond mmr on smurfs. Is it going to be as straightforward as a typical jungler? No, but is it playable and able to succeed? Absolutely, you just have to know how to play

> From my perspective, Magus doesn't work in the same way that Juggernaut didn't work. For tanks, the problem was that buying Juggernaut didn't help with clears. For mages, it's that buying Magus doesn't offer them enough mana to clear. This is the same core problem, and the same type of solution will work.

From my perspective, there isn't enough incentive to take mages into the jungle, aside from a few obvious examples. What is an underfed mage going to offer that a tank or bruiser couldn't do better? There are always going to be certain champions that are better suited for particular roles than others, that's just a fact of the game. I think there are more pressing issues preventing a lot of mages from being god-tier junglers than just mana sustain; I'd say it's actually fairly low on the list of concerns, especially given all the methods of dealing with it.

Here's the difference between magus and juggernaut; tanks *as a class* were struggling in jungle compared to bruisers; that isn't the case with mages. Sure Sejuani was pretty strong, but no where near as strong as Fiddlesticks was in jungle (before Cinderhulk, Sejuani was sitting at like, 51-52% win rate in plat+ IIRC; Fiddlesticks has been at ~55%+ for like a year). Mages in jungle suffer more on an individual level than tank junglers; the solution therefore is, if you want to support a jungle playstyle, buff them individually rather than just making a blanket buff that will throw already balanced champions way out of whack. Simply buffing mana in jungle isn't suddenly going to make Malzahar jungle a pro pick. If you actually want these champions to be junglers, give them a legitimate way to succeed; mana isn't going to do enough, especially without harming the rest of the game environment.

You are making mistakes in your item builds.  Your results will improve if you:

* Stop building components for multiple items before finishing one
* Always rush your jungle item
* Never rush chalice

I don't think further discussion on this topic is productive.

Stop thinking about item builds as some kind of dogma, this isn't smite, there's no auto buy function in this game.

Yes you *typically* want to focus on building one item at a time, but you want to know what else is ideal? Not running oom because you're too stubborn to deviate from some narrow build path you found on freaking mobafire.

This is the difference between high Elo players and low Elo players. Low Elo players come on reddit and whine at riot every time they lose a game, high Elo players learn the game and figure out how to make things work.

EDIT: I'm in no way saying I'm a high elo player; I suck crap at this game, but I'm *learning* from smarter players, not just your random one trick pony elo booster diamond player, but players and coaches who really understand the game and know how to break things down. My individual ideas might suck at times (again, I suck at this game), but the concepts still ring true.

One mage in particular i find does very well in the jungle is Orianna, between her passive and the ball's Q and E, there's really no problem clearing any camps at any time. The issue with her comes more when it's time to gank, unless she has an engage heavy team (hello Malphite/Yasuo/Leona), she can't really usually pull off good ganks. That, and as a mage, she's slow but that's a given until you can afford to spam W.

That said, i always find it a bit sad to build the Magus enchant because it brings nothing something else can't give, in the end.

You could probably have a lot of success with Lulu if you want; her autos also deal a lot of damage because of her passive, plus she has a ton of utility and flexibility in her builds that she can do a lot with a little of gold.

> That said, i always find it a bit sad to build the Magus enchant because it brings nothing something else can't give, in the end.

I mean, you can say the same thing about Warrior enchant. It's basically a brutalizer with a bit more AD.

I think Mana Regeneration is an issue facing all of the mage characters, not just the jungle ones.  Even in your list of viable junglers you've mentioned that they require Blue buff + tear for the entire game to function.  Which means you assume the mid laner is a mana-less assassin or has a mana regain mechanic?

Note that I'm in agreement that being a mage doesn't necessitate a special jungle item, just that mages as a kind of character are really shitty now with the mana regen options.

I think it's worth mentioning that characters like {{champion:60}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:121}} have been ruined.  They are very weak in the jungle but they also can't go into any lane atm.  Hoping jungle diversity makes them viable again someday.

> Even in your list of viable junglers you've mentioned that they require Blue buff + tear for the entire game to function.

I wasn't so much saying that they require it so much as offering a variety of options for people trying to play a certain champion in jungle. I also agree that mana regen is worse early for mages than it was in season 4, but I've never found it to be a problem, especially not one that can't be worked around with smarter play and planning; there *are* options in the game (ones that don't even require a huge trade-off or anything), if the player isn't taking those options, it's their fault, not the game's.

> I think it's worth mentioning that characters like [elise, eve, kha] have been ruined.

Kha'Zix is perfectly fine. I'm serious. Go watch NB3 play him, he's got like a 60% win rate in mid-high challenger on him. People keep thinking Kha'Zix is useless because you actually have to be smart about how you play him now.

Elise and Eve have been gutted, plain and simple. I expect them to receive a steady stream of buffs throughout the year once Riot figures out what to do with them. It isn't an issue of jungle diversity, it's an issue of Riot butchering two champions and not giving them anything in return. Honestly I see Eve getting more buffs if Mandrake Ward comes out, and Elise might be in line for a light rework. That's my guess.

So,what if Riot just buff those mage junglers?
That way we don't make the already strong Ap junglers (Fuck {{champion:76}} ) even stronger but can still make the other AP junglers,who are struggling in the jungle, better.

Though I have to ask who are the AP junglers.Besides the few you mentioned,the only ones I can think of are {{champion:60}} (though most build her tanky) {{champion:28}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:79}} {{champion:10}} {{champion:4}} (good old UOL).Who are the other AP junglers?

I would rather get mana sustain into a reasonable place for junglers in general, then nerf the outliers.  More efficient to make system level changes, then nerf a couple, than it is to buff tons of mages into jungle viability without breaking them for laning.

TF was played as on-hit TF, not AP TF (ie built attack speed and on hit effects, instead of AP).

They're talking about bringing stuff like Brand, Karma, Morgana, etc. into jungle, which can either already work, or be made to work through changes with itemization/runes/masteries/playing more intelligently, or they have larger issues that mana regen alone wouldn't even touch.

Aside from what you mentioned, what I'd like to see come back to the jungle is dedicated counterjunglers. Right now, counterjungling is high risk low reward for a variety of reasons (trinkets, wolf smite, s4 changes to jungle exp, buffs being pretty irrelevant compared to previous seasons, etc). I just played as {{champion:111}}  against {{champion:20}} which should have been a nightmare matchup, but because of what's happened to counterjungling {{champion:20}} might as well have not even been in the game, even though he did the {{champion:20}} thing reasonably well.

Bring back counterjungling because it's fun and often very intense (farming devourer stacks can stay out of the meta though).

Posted here for a lack of a better place;

Also, on DJ Sona, on the first swap of music only, as far as i can tell, there is a very short but very noticeable lag spike that affects my enire team. That bug happened every time on the Rift so far.

Concerning the League of Tanks; I for one am very happy. I always felt it was silly a champion with the right items could murder a tank so fast they became irrelevant. An assassin for one (i think, anyway) should be generally unable to kill a full health tank in one full combo only. I'm actually more worried about Tanks dealing too much damage to the squishies. Things like Trinity Force and Botrk on some tanks are maybe... too fantastic sometimes?

Just because a Red comments doesn't mean you need to, or should, post all of your own concerns just to try to get their attention. It just overcrowds the post and thread that they commented in. Conversations should try to stay relevant to the topic being discussed unless the general conversation shifts together.

Though I feel that Skirmisher's has its upsides/uses, the change of its on-hit damage to a DoT makes the damage reduction/vision its main selling point, making it more of a supporting item than an aggressive, dueling-centric one. Not saying I want the old on-hit damage back (we've seen what comes of that...*shudder*...), but the thematic and gameplay aspects of the items seem skewed. Perhaps changing the damage against champions to magic/physical damage on-hit to make it worthwhile but counterable with defenses.

My real issue, though, is Poacher's. Of the four new smites, I've always felt that this one felt a bit...**too** specialized. Not only are the item's uses polarizing, but it is also the only smite buff that doesn't have any secondary uses (Stalker's gives MS when fleeing, Skirmishers doubles as an exhaust, even Trailblazer can delay pushes with its AoE/Stun). On that note, you'll rarely prioritize its primary use unless you're living in the enemy jungle mid-lategame, in which case you wouldn't even need a means of escape anyways. 

Instead, why not make it more focused on vision, perhaps spawning a wolf spirit-like sentry that patrols the area. This would make the item equal to the others in terms of versatility, letting it cover a more universal aspect of the jungle than aggressive invasion.

Skirmishers actually fulfills its purpose excellently, in that it allows a low damage tank to gain a lot of extra survivability and damage when invaded, or be able to challenge the enemy jungler on their own side of the map without fear of being eviscerated.

UNIQUE PASSIVE- Duelist's Smite: Modifies Smite into Duelist's Smite. Smite can now be used on a champion, minion, or monster to increase damage you deal to the target by 10% and reducing damage the target deals to you by 20% as well as granting 30 tenacity against crowd control effects from the target. This effect lasts for 8 seconds. During this time, if the target moves more than 700 units away from the caster, they are slowed by 10% (+1% per level) and are revealed.
